SENT.plain: A 65-year-old man with acute lymphoblastic leukemia of B-cell origin is described
The patient had many distinctive features including a very high blast cell count, hepatomegaly, hemorrhagic diathesis and a fulminant clinical course
Immunological studies showed the blast cells to have surface characteristics of B-lymphoid cells (IgG kappa)
These cells had moderate amounts of deeply basophilic cytoplasm without granules
Most cells contained empty cytoplasmic vacuoles (L3 according to the FBA classification)
Autopsy confirmed wide-spread leukemia involving the bone marrow, spleen, liver, kidneys, lungs, adrenals, thyroid gland, stomach, rectum, root ganglia and lymph nodes
This case is an example of acute lymphoblastic leukemia with Burkitt's tumor cells (L3)
